RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH:
Master's Degree in Physics (2000) and Doctorate in Physics (2004), at University of Rome 'La Sapienza'. 
Major interests in Statistical Mechanics, Complex Systems and Quantum Mechanics.
Currently Professor at the Institute of Phsycis of Universidade Federal da Bahia, Salvador (BA), Brazil. 

Research activity centered on the study of classical and quantum systems by means of analytical,
numerical, and probabilistic methods. Technical expertise with original results in: 
Quantum Many Body Systems and Random Models on Complex Networks.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: master's at Physics from La Sapienza-Universit degli Studi di Roma (2000) and doctorate at Physics from University of Rome "La Sapienza" (2004). Has experience in Physics, focusing on Physical Statistics and Thermodynamics

OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES:
Teaching activity:
A.Y. 2002/2003 Assistant for "Matematica II", Calculus II, University of Rome ?Roma Tre?
A.Y. 2001/2002 Assistant for "Fisica Generale", General Physics, University of Rome ?La Sapienza?

The paper EPL, 113 40002 (2016),
has been selected to be included in the EPL Highlights of 2016 to celebrate the most influential
research published in the journal EPL from the last year (2016).

I was given the opportunity to help for the organization of the SBF meeting held in Natal, RN, 3-7 September 2016.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Thermalization of Many-Body Systems and Quantum Computation at Low Temperatures (Bolsista de Produtividade em Pesquisa do CNPq - Nvel 2)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Among all the possible processes that an open system can follow, thermalization is one of the most important one, nevertheless, little is known about its rigorous understanding and analysis. In this project, we consider sufficiently simple - yet not trivial - systems put in contact with a thermal reservoir in
order to analyze their characteristic thermalization times. We are mainly interested in systems undergoing quantum phase transitions and we will investigate how their characteristic thermalization times scale with the system size. Such characteristic times provide essential information in quantum computation. In particular, for modern supposedly large-scale quantum computers, like D-wave
systems, which aim to work at very low temperatures, the knowledge of the characteristic thermalization times turns out to be crucial.
